metadata.title: Mortgage Balloon Payment Calculator — Bi‑Weekly & Monthly Scenarios
metadata.description: Calculate periodic payments and the balloon (remaining) balance for loans that amortize over one term but have a balloon due earlier. Supports monthly or bi‑weekly payment frequencies and two workflows: from original loan terms or from an existing remaining balance.

from_terms.label: From original loan terms (amortization ≠ balloon)
from_terms.description: Compute the periodic payment based on a full amortization schedule, then report the remaining balance (balloon) after a specified number of years.

balloon_balance.label: Balloon payment (remaining balance at balloon date)

from_remaining_balance.label: From existing remaining balance (convert schedule)
from_remaining_balance.description: Start from a current remaining balance and remaining amortization, compute the periodic payment at the chosen frequency, and report the balloon due after a chosen number of years.

introduction: This calculator computes the scheduled periodic payment (monthly or bi‑weekly) based on a full amortization schedule, and then returns the balloon amount — the remaining principal due if a balloon payment falls before full amortization. It supports two workflows: starting from original loan terms, or from an existing remaining balance.

Use the bi‑weekly option to estimate the effect of 26 payments per year (commonly used in bi‑weekly programs). Results are estimates for planning and do not replace lender payoff statements or official disclosures.
methodology: Payments are computed using standard amortization formulas. The scheduled periodic payment is the fixed payment that amortizes the principal over the chosen amortization term at the chosen payment frequency.

The balloon amount is the remaining loan balance after the specified number of payments. For 0% interest the formulas simplify to linear principal reduction; otherwise compound interest formulas are used.

Calculations assume consistent payment timing (equal periods) and that interest compounds at the same periodic frequency as payments. Changes in escrow, fees, late payments, interest compounding conventions, or lender rounding rules will affect actual payoff values.
how_is_calculated: Number of payments for amortization n = amortization_years * payments_per_year
Scheduled periodic payment (Pmt) = if r==0 then Principal / n else Principal * r / (1 - (1+r)^-n)
Number of payments before balloon k = floor(balloon_years * payments_per_year)
Remaining balance after k payments (balloon) = Principal*(1+r)^k - Pmt * (( (1+r)^k - 1 ) / r) (use linear reduction if r==0)
examples: Example 1: $300,000 loan, 5.0% APR, 30‑year amortization, bi‑weekly payments, balloon after 5 years — calculator returns the bi‑weekly payment and the remaining balance at 5 years.

Example 2: Existing remaining balance $200,000, 4.5% APR, 20 years remaining amortization, switch to bi‑weekly payments, balloon after 3 years — calculator returns the new periodic payment and the balloon due in 3 years.

faqs.question: Does 'bi‑weekly' mean half of the monthly payment?
faqs.answer: No. Bi‑weekly typically uses 26 payments per year (every two weeks). Half the monthly payment equals 24 half‑monthly payments per year. The calculator uses 26 payments per year when bi‑weekly is selected.

faqs.question: Why does the balloon amount differ from the loan principal?
faqs.answer: The balloon amount is the remaining principal after making scheduled payments for the selected period; it reflects principal reduction and accrued interest and is generally less than the original principal unless no payments have been made.

faqs.question: How accurate are the results?
faqs.answer: Results use standard amortization formulas and typical rounding. They are estimates for planning. Actual payoff amounts depend on lender rounding, per‑period interest day counts, fees, and prepayment policies. Always verify with lender payoff statements.

faqs.question: What if interest rate or payment frequency changes mid‑loan?
faqs.answer: This calculator assumes fixed APR and a consistent payment frequency for the period evaluated. If terms change mid‑loan, recalculate for each interval or consult your lender for an official amortization.

faqs.question: Is this a replacement for legal or lending documents?
faqs.answer: No. Use this tool for planning and comparison. The lender's note, servicing agreement, payoff statement, and closing documents govern legal obligations.

glossary.definition: The schedule of periodic payments that gradually reduce the loan principal to zero over a specified term.
A lump‑sum payment due at a specified time before or at the end of the loan that pays off the remaining principal.
The interest rate applied each payment period, calculated as APR divided by the number of payment periods per year.
A payment frequency where payments are made every two weeks, typically resulting in 26 payments per year.
The fixed payment amount per period calculated to amortize the loan over the chosen amortization term.

summary: Use the 'Original loan terms' workflow to compute the scheduled payment based on a full amortization term and find the balloon due at a chosen earlier date.
Use the 'Existing remaining balance' workflow when you have a current balance and remaining amortization and want to convert to monthly or bi‑weekly payments and project a balloon.
